Public perception of climate change: the icons dataset in the hyper2 package

Robin K. S. Hankin

Source: vignettes/icons.Rmd
icons.Rmd

To cite the hyper2 package in publications, please use Hankin (2017). This short document analyses the climate change dataset introduced by O‚ÄôNeill (2007) and discussed in the hyperdirichlet R package (Hankin 2010), but using the improved hyper2 package instead. O‚ÄôNeill and Hulme (2009) observe that lay perception of climate change is a complex and interesting process, and here we assess the engagement of non-experts by the use of ‚Äúicons‚Äù (this word is standard in this context. An icon is a ‚Äúrepresentative symbol‚Äù) that illustrate different impacts of climate change.

Here we analyse results of one experiment (O‚ÄôNeill 2007), in which subjects were presented with a set of icons of climate change and asked to identify which of them they found most concerning. Six icons were used: PB [polar bears, which face extinction through loss of ice floe hunting grounds], NB [the Norfolk Broads, which flood due to intense rainfall events], L [London flooding, as a result of sea level rise], THC [the thermo-haline circulation, which may slow or stop as a result of anthropogenic modification of the water cycle], OA [oceanic acidification as a result of anthropogenic emissions of CO2{\mathrm C}{\mathrm O}_2], and WAIS [the West Antarctic Ice Sheet, which is rapidly calving as a result of climate change]. Methodological constraints dictated that each respondent could be presented with a maximum of four icons. The R idiom below (dataset icons in the package) shows the experimental results.

library("hyper2",quietly=TRUE)
M <- icons_table # saves typing
M
##       NB  L PB THC OA WAIS
##  [1,]  5  3 NA   4 NA    3
##  [2,]  3 NA  5   8 NA    2
##  [3,] NA  4  9   2 NA    1
##  [4,] 10  3 NA   3  4   NA
##  [5,]  4 NA  5   6  3   NA
##  [6,] NA  4  3   1  3   NA
##  [7,]  5  1 NA  NA  1    2
##  [8,]  5 NA  1  NA  1    1
##  [9,] NA  9  7  NA  2    0

(M is called icons_table in the package). Each row of M corresponds to a particular cue given to respondents. The first row, for example, means that a total of 5+3+4+3=155+3+4+3=15 people were shown icons NB, L, THC, WAIS [column names of the the non-NA entries]; 5 people chose NB as most concerning, 3 chose L, and so on. The dataset is more fully described in the package. The builtin icons likelihood function in the hyper2 package may be created by using the saffy() function:

icons
## log(L^24 * (L + NB + OA + THC)^-20 * (L + NB + OA + WAIS)^-9 * (L + NB
## + THC + WAIS)^-15 * (L + OA + PB + THC)^-11 * (L + OA + PB + WAIS)^-18
## * (L + PB + THC + WAIS)^-16 * NB^32 * (NB + OA + PB + THC)^-18 * (NB +
## OA + PB + WAIS)^-8 * (NB + PB + THC + WAIS)^-18 * OA^14 * PB^30 *
## THC^24 * WAIS^9)
icons == saffy(icons_table)  # should be TRUE
## [1] TRUE

At this point, the icons object as created above is mathematically identical to the icons object in the hyperdirichlet package (and indeed the hyper2 package), but the terms might appear in a different order due to disordR discipline.

Analysis of the icons dataset

The first step is to find the maximum likelihood estimate for the icons likelihood:

options("digits" = 4)
(mic <- maxp(icons))
##      NB       L      PB     THC      OA    WAIS 
## 0.25230 0.17364 0.22458 0.17011 0.11069 0.06867
dotchart(mic,pch=16)

We also need the log-likelihood at an unconstrained maximum:

L1 <- loglik(indep(mic),icons)
options(digits=9)
L1
## [1] -174.997435

We see agreement to 4 decimal places with the value given in the hyperdirichlet package. The next step is to assess a number of hypotheses concerning the relative sizes of p1p_1 through p6p_6.

Hypothesis testing.

Below, I investigate a number of inequality hypotheses about p1,‚Ä¶,p6p_1,\ldots, p_6. The general analysis proceeds as follows; we can use H0:p1=1/6H_0\colon p_1=1/6 as an example but the method applies to any observation. I consider the general case first, then modifications for one-sided hypotheses.

  • We have an observation ùí™{\mathcal O} and wish to quantify the strength of evidence to support this.
  • Translate our observation into a hypothesis phrased in terms as a restriction on parameter space.
  • State a null hypothesis and alternative. For example, we might have H0:p1=1/6H_0\colon p_1=1/6 and HA:p1‚â†1/6H_A\colon p_1\neq 1/6, and HAH_A is the complement of H0H_0. We sometimes write HA:‚àëpi=1H_A\colon\sum p_i=1, ignoring the (measure zero) H0H_0.
  • We then attempt to reject H0H_0 and to do this we perform two likelihood maximizations: one unconstrained, corresponding to HAH_A, and one constrained, corresponding to H0H_0.
  • We calculate ‚ÑíH0:=argmaxp‚ààH0‚Ñí(p){\mathcal L}_{H_0} :=\operatorname{argmax}_{p\in H_0}{\mathcal L}(p) and ‚ÑíHA:=argmaxp‚ààHA‚Ñí(p){\mathcal L}_{H_A} := \operatorname{argmax}_{p\in H_A}{\mathcal L}(p) and observe that, in general, ùí™{\mathcal O} implies the strict inequality ‚ÑíHA>‚ÑíH0{\mathcal L}_{H_A} > {\mathcal L}_{H_0}.
  • Calculate the likelihood ratio R=‚ÑíHA/‚ÑíH0>1R={\mathcal L}_{H_A}/{\mathcal L}_{H_0}>1 or equivalently the support for H0H_0, Œõ=logR>0\Lambda = \log R>0.
  • We may either use Edwards‚Äôs criterion of two units of support per degree of freedom, or Wilks‚Äôs theorem: H0‚Üí2Œõ‚àºœád2H_0\longrightarrow 2\Lambda\sim\chi^2_d. If we are considering inequality hypotheses, we have d=1d=1.
  • If the criterion is met we may reject H0H_0 and infer that HAH_A is the case.

As another example, consider H0:p1=p2=p3H_0\colon p_1=p_2=p_3. The vector ùê©‚àà{(p1,‚Ä¶,p6)|‚àëpi=1}{\mathbf p}\in \left\{\left.\left(p_1,\ldots,p_6\right)\right| \sum p_i=1\right\} is a point in a 5-dimensional manifold, and H0H_0 asserts that ùê©‚àà{(p1,p1,p1,p4,p5,p6)|3p1+p4+p5+p6=1}{\mathbf p}\in \left\{\left.\left(p_1,p_1,p_1,p_4,p_5,p_6\right)\right| 3p_1+p_4+p_5+p_6=1\right\}, that is, a 3-dimensional manifold. The null imposes a loss of two degrees of freedom.

The logic above operates for one-sided tests. We might observe that p1ÃÇ\hat{p_1} is the largest and wish to test a null of p1‚â§1/6p_1\leqslant 1/6 against an alternative of p1>1/6p_1>1/6. Note that the one-sided p-value and likelihood ratio statistic are the same as the two-sided values.

Below I will rework some of the hypotheses tested in the hyperdirichlet package, with consistent labelling of null and alternative hypotheses, and renumbering

Equality of strengths

The most straightforward null would be the hypothesis of player equality, specifically:

HE:p1=p2=‚ãØ=pn=1n. H_E\colon p_1=p_2=\cdots=p_n=\frac{1}{n}.

(‚ÄúE‚Äù for equal). This was not carried out in Hankin (2010), because I had not thought of it. Testing HEH_E is implemented in the package as test.equalp(). Note that because HEH_E is a point hypothesis we would have n‚àí1n-1 degrees of freedom (because H0H_0 has n‚àí1n-1 df).

equalp.test(icons)
## 
##  Constrained support maximization
## 
## data:  icons
## null hypothesis: NB = L = PB = THC = OA = WAIS
## null estimate:
##          NB           L          PB         THC          OA        WAIS 
## 0.166666667 0.166666667 0.166666667 0.166666667 0.166666667 0.166666667 
## (argmax, constrained optimization)
## Support for null:  -184.37715 + K
## 
## alternative hypothesis:  sum p_i=1 
## alternative estimate:
##           NB            L           PB          THC           OA         WAIS 
## 0.2523041150 0.1736443259 0.2245818764 0.1701128100 0.1106860420 0.0686708306 
## (argmax, free optimization)
## Support for alternative:  -174.997435 + K
## 
## degrees of freedom: 5
## support difference = 9.37971546
## p-value: 0.00213083779

Hypothesis 1: p1=1/6p_1 = 1/6

Following the analysis in Hankin (2010), and restated above, we first observe that NB [the Norfolk Broads] is the icon with the largest estimated probability with p1ÃÇ‚âÉ0.25\hat{p_1}\simeq 0.25 (O‚ÄôNeill gives a number of theoretical reasons to expect p1p_1 to be large). This would suggest that p1p_1 is in fact large, in some sense, and here I show how to assess this statement statistically. Consider the hypothesis H0:p1=1/6H_0\colon p_1=1/6, and as per the protocol above we will try to reject it.

To that end, we perform a constrained optimization, with (active) constraint that p1‚â§1/6p_1\leqslant 1/6 (note that the inequality constraint allows us to use fast maxp(), which has access to derivatives). We note the support at the evaluate and then compare this support with the support at the unconstrained evaluate; if the difference in support is large then this constitutes strong evidence for HAH_A and then would conclude that p1>1/6p_1 > 1/6. In package idiom, the optimization is implemented by the specificp.test() suite of functions; these work by imposing additional constraints to the maxp() function via the fcm and fcv arguments. Using the defaults we have:

specificp.test(icons,1)
## 
##  Constrained support maximization
## 
## data:  H
## null hypothesis: sum p_i=1, p_1 = 0.166666667
## null estimate:
##           NB            L           PB          THC           OA         WAIS 
## 0.1666666514 0.1935760159 0.2520057446 0.1848196512 0.1248364824 0.0780954545 
## (argmax, constrained optimization)
## Support for null:  -177.614346 + K
## 
## alternative hypothesis:  sum p_i=1 
## alternative estimate:
##           NB            L           PB          THC           OA         WAIS 
## 0.2523041150 0.1736443259 0.2245818764 0.1701128100 0.1106860420 0.0686708306 
## (argmax, free optimization)
## Support for alternative:  -174.997435 + K
## 
## degrees of freedom: 1
## support difference = 2.61691171
## p-value: 0.0221517868 (two sided)

which tests a null of p1‚â§16p_1\leqslant\frac{1}{6}; see how the evaluate under the null is on the boundary and we have p1ÃÇ=16\hat{p_1}=\frac{1}{6}. Compare the support of 2.607 with 2.608181 from the hyperdirichlet package. This exceeds Edwards‚Äôs two-units-of-support criterion; the pp-value is obtained by applying Wilks‚Äôs theorem on the asymptotic distribution of 2.

Both these criteria indicate that we may reject that hypothesis that p1‚â§1/6p_1\leqslant 1/6 and thereby infer p1>16p_1>\frac{1}{6}.

Hypothesis 2: p1‚â•max(p2,‚Ä¶,p6)p_1\geqslant\max\left(p_2,\ldots,p_6\right)

We observe that NB (the Norfolk Broads) has large strength, and hypothesise that it is in fact stronger than any other icon. This is another constrained likelihood maximization, although this one is not possible with convex constraints. In the language of the generic procedure given above, we would have

H0:(p1‚â§p2)‚à™(p1‚â§p3)‚à™(p1‚â§p4)‚à™(p1‚â§p5)‚à™(p1‚â§p6) H_0\colon (p_1\leqslant p_2)\cup (p_1\leqslant p_3)\cup (p_1\leqslant p_4)\cup (p_1\leqslant p_5)\cup (p_1\leqslant p_6)

H0¬Ø:(p1>p2)‚à©(p1>p3)‚à©(p1>p4)‚à©(p1>p5)‚à©(p1>p6) \overline{H_0}\colon (p_1 > p_2)\cap (p_1 > p_3)\cap (p_1 > p_4)\cap (p_1 > p_5)\cap (p_1 > p_6)

(although note that H0H_0 has nonzero measure). In words, H0H_0 states that p1p_1 is smaller than p2p_2, or p1p_1 is smaller than p3p_3, etc; while H0¬Ø\overline{H_0} states that p1p_1 is larger than p2p_2, and is larger than p3p_3, and so on. Considering the evaluate, we see that ‚ÑíH0<‚ÑíH0¬Ø{\mathcal L}_{H_0} < {\mathcal L}_{\overline{H_0}}, so optimizing over H0¬Ø\overline{H_0} is equivalent to unconstrained optimization [of course, the intrinsic constraints pi‚â•0,‚àëpi‚â§1p_i\geqslant 0, \sum p_i\leqslant 1 have to be respected]. Here, H0¬Ø\overline{H_0} is regions of (p1,‚Ä¶,p6)(p_1,\ldots,p_6) with p1p_1 being greater than at least one of p2,‚Ä¶,p6p_2,\ldots,p_6. The union of convex sets is not necessarily convex (e.g.¬†a two-way Venn diagram). As far as I can see, the only way to do it is to perform a sequence of five constrained optimizations: p1‚â§p2,p1‚â§p3,p1‚â§p4,p1‚â§p5p_1\leqslant p_2, p_1\leqslant p_3, p_1\leqslant p_4, p_1\leqslant p_5. The fillup constraint would be p1‚â§p6‚Üí2p1+p2+‚ãØ+p5‚â§1p_1\leqslant p_6\longrightarrow 2p_1+p_2+\cdots +p_5\leqslant 1. We then choose the largest likelihood from the five.

o <- function(Ul,Cl,startp,give=FALSE){
    small <- 1e-4  #  ensure start at an interior point
    if(missing(startp)){startp <- small*(1:5)+rep(0.1,5)}           
    out <- maxp(icons, startp=small*(1:5)+rep(0.1,5), give=TRUE, fcm=Ul,fcv=Cl)
    if(give){
        return(out)
    }else{
        return(out$value)
    }
}

p2max <- o(c(-1, 1, 0, 0, 0), 0)  # p1 <= p2
p3max <- o(c(-1, 0, 1, 0, 0), 0)  # p1 <= p3
p4max <- o(c(-1, 0, 0, 1, 0), 0)  # p1 <= p4
p5max <- o(c(-1, 0, 0, 0, 1), 0)  # p1 <= p5
p6max <- o(c(-2,-1,-1,-1,-1),-1)  # p1 <= p6 (fillup)

(the final line is different because p6p_6 is the fillup value).

likes <- c(p2max,p3max,p4max,p5max,p6max)
likes
## [1] -175.810521 -175.081858 -175.983441 -178.204173 -181.515387
ml <- max(likes) 
ml
## [1] -175.081858

Thus the first element of likes corresponds to the maximum likelihood, constrained so that p1‚â§p2p_1\leqslant p_2; the second element corresponds to the constraint that p1‚â§p3p_1\leqslant p_3, and so on. The largest likelihood is the easiest constraint to break, in this case p1‚â§p3p_1\leqslant p_3: this makes sense because p3p_3 has the second highest MLE after p1p_1. The extra likelihood is given by

L1-ml
## [1] 0.0844236585

(the hyperdirichlet package gives 0.0853 here, a surprisingly small discrepancy given the difficulties of optimizing over a nonconvex region). We conclude that there is no evidence for p1‚â•max(p2,‚Ä¶,p6)p_1\geqslant\max\left(p_2,\ldots,p_6\right).

It‚Äôs worth looking at the evaluate too:

o2 <- function(Ul,Cl){
  jj <-o(Ul,Cl,give=TRUE)
  out <- c(jj[[1]],1-sum(jj[[1]]),jj[[2]])
  names(out) <- c("p1","p2","p3","p4","p5","p6","support")
  return(out)
}
rbind(
o2(c(-1, 1, 0, 0, 0), 0),  # p1 <= p2
o2(c(-1, 0, 1, 0, 0), 0),  # p1 <= p3
o2(c(-1, 0, 0, 1, 0), 0),  # p1 <= p4
o2(c(-1, 0, 0, 0, 1), 0),  # p1 <= p5
o2(c(-2,-1,-1,-1,-1),-1)   # p1 <= p6
)
##               p1          p2          p3          p4          p5           p6
## [1,] 0.211674267 0.211674268 0.226222108 0.169452254 0.111434270 0.0695428329
## [2,] 0.238552641 0.174097331 0.238552998 0.169739010 0.110517185 0.0685408341
## [3,] 0.209075905 0.175046706 0.228380262 0.209075907 0.110003635 0.0684175840
## [4,] 0.181049944 0.176566992 0.228589945 0.165076513 0.181049945 0.0676666608
## [5,] 0.159212367 0.174456695 0.234412699 0.168868084 0.103837779 0.1592123762
##          support
## [1,] -175.810521
## [2,] -175.081858
## [3,] -175.983441
## [4,] -178.204173
## [5,] -181.515387

In the above, the evaluate is the first five columns (p6p_6 being the fillup) and the final column is the log-likelihood at the evaluate. See how the constraint is active in each line: M[1,] == M[1:5,2:6]. Also note that the largest log-likelihood is the second row: if we were to violate any of the constraints, it would be p1<p3p_1<p_3, consistent with the fact that p3p_3 (polar bears) has the second highest strength, after p1p_1.

Low frequency responses

The next hypothesis follows from the observed smallness of p5ÃÇ\hat{p_5} (ocean acidification) and p6ÃÇ\hat{p_6} (West Antarctic Ice Sheet) at 0.111 and 0.069 respectively. These two strengths correspond to ‚Äúdistant‚Äù concerns and O‚ÄôNeill had reason to consider their sum (which she argued would be small). Thus we specify H0:p5+p6‚â§13H_0\colon p_5+p_6\leqslant \frac{1}{3}.

The optimizing constraint of p5+p6‚â•13p_5+p_6\geqslant\frac{1}{3} translates to an operational constraint of ‚àíp1‚àíp2‚àíp3‚àíp4‚â•‚àí23-p_1-p_2-p_3-p_4\geqslant-\frac{2}{3} (because p5+p6=1‚àíp1‚àíp2‚àíp3‚àíp4p_5+p_6=1-p_1-p_2-p_3-p_4):

jj <- o(c(-1,-1,-1,-1,0) , -2/3, give=TRUE,start=indep((1:6)/21))$value
jj
## [1] -182.21078

then the extra support is

L1-jj
## [1] 7.21334577

(compare 7.711396 in hyperdirichlet, not sure why the discrepancy is so large).

Final example

The final example is motivated by the fact that both the distant icons p5p_5 and p6p_6 had lower strength than any of the local icons p1,‚Ä¶,p4p_1,\ldots, p_4. Thus we would have H0:max{p5,p6}‚â•min{p1,p2,p3,p4}H_0\colon\max\left\{p_5,p_6\right\}\geqslant\min\left\{p_1,p_2,p_3,p_4\right\}. This means the null optimization is constrained so that at least one of {p5,p6}\left\{p_5,p_6\right\} exceeds at least one of {p1,p2,p3,p4}\left\{p_1,p_2,p_3,p_4\right\}. So we have the union of the various possibilities:

$$\begin{equation}\label{eq:Habar}H_0= \overline{H_A}\colon \bigcup_{j\in\left\{5,6\right\}\atop k\in\left\{1,2,3,4\right\}} \left\{\left(p_1,p_2,p_3,p_4,p_5,p_6\right)\left|\sum p_i=1, p_j\geqslant p_k\right.\right\} \end{equation}$$

The fillup value p6p_6 behaves differently in this context and p6‚â•p2p_6\geqslant p_2, say, translates to ‚àíp1‚àí2p2‚àíp3‚àíp4‚àíp5‚â•‚àí1-p_1-2p_2-p_3-p_4-p_5\geqslant -1.

small <- 1e-4
start <- indep(c(small,small,small,small,0.5-2*small,0.5-2*small))
jj <- c(
   o(c(-1, 0, 0, 0, 1), 0,start=start),  # p1 >= p5
   o(c( 0,-1, 0, 0, 1), 0,start=start),  # p2 >= p5
   o(c( 0, 0,-1, 0, 1), 0,start=start),  # p3 >= p5
   o(c( 0, 0, 0,-1, 1), 0,start=start),  # p4 >= p5

   o(c(-2,-1,-1,-1,-1),-1,start=start),  # p1 >= p6
   o(c(-1,-2,-1,-1,-1),-1,start=start),  # p2 >= p6
   o(c(-1,-1,-2,-1,-1),-1,start=start),  # p3 >= p6
   o(c(-1,-1,-1,-2,-1),-1,start=start)   # p4 >= p6
   )
jj
## [1] -178.204173 -175.894803 -177.318942 -175.747872 -181.515387 -177.978365
## [7] -180.406280 -177.753717

Above, the elements of vector jj are the maximum likelihoods for each of the separate components of the parameter space allowed under H0H_0. Note that these components are not disjoint. So the maximum likelihood for the whole of allowable parameters under H0H_0 would be the maximum of these maxima:

max(jj)
## [1] -175.747872

This corresponds to the fourth component of H0H_0, viz p4=p5p_4=p_5. The extra support is thus

L1-max(jj)
## [1] 0.750437512

(compare hyperdirichlet which gives 3.16, not sure why the difference although if pressed I would point to hyper2 using multiple walkers in its optimization [defaulting to n=10n=10] ). We should look at the maximum value:

o(c( 0, 0, 0,-1, 1), 0,give=TRUE,start=start)
## $par
## [1] 0.250298786 0.173616322 0.224279186 0.141760611 0.141760626
## 
## $value
## [1] -175.747872
## 
## $counts
## function gradient 
##      551       86 
## 
## $convergence
## [1] 0
## 
## $message
## NULL
## 
## $outer.iterations
## [1] 2
## 
## $barrier.value
## [1] 0.000172310891
## 
## $likes
## [1] -175.747872
## 
## $evaluate
##           NB            L           PB          THC           OA         WAIS 
## 0.2502987861 0.1736163215 0.2242791861 0.1417606108 0.1417606257 0.0682844698

So the evaluate is at the boundary, for p4=p5p_4=p_5; THC and OA have the same Bradley-Terry strength. The small amount of extra support given by allowing an unconstrained optimization would suggest that there is no strong evidence for the contention investigated, viz ‚Äúboth the distant icons p5p_5 and p6p_6 have lower strength than any of the local icons p1,‚Ä¶,p4p_1,\ldots, p_4‚Äù.

References

Hankin, R. K. S. 2010. ‚ÄúA Generalization of the Dirichlet Distribution.‚Äù Journal of Statistical Software 33 (11): 1‚Äì18. https://doi.org/10.18637/jss.v033.i11.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî. 2017. ‚ÄúPartial Rank Data with the hyper2 Package: Likelihood Functions for Generalized Bradley-Terry Models.‚Äù The R Journal 9 (2): 429‚Äì39.
O‚ÄôNeill, S. J. 2007. ‚ÄúAn Iconic Approach to Representing Climate Change.‚Äù PhD thesis, School of Environmental Science, University of East Anglia.
O‚ÄôNeill, S. J., and M. Hulme. 2009. ‚ÄúAn Iconic Approach for Representing Climate Change.‚Äù Global Environmental Change 19: 402‚Äì10.
